metadata.titleEn: Antarctic sea ice daily 1 km cloud-reconstructed albedo dataset (2012-2021)
metadata.description: The Antarctic sea ice cloud-reconstructed albedo dataset, with spatial resolution of 1 km and temporal resolution of 1 day, covering the period from January 2012 to December 2021. Due to the snow and ice albedo feedback mechanism, the Antarctic sea ice albedo plays a crucial role in regulating the Earth's radiation budget and controlling polar climate change. The production of this dataset uses the VIIRS 1 km surface reflectance product (VNP09GA) as one of the main input data. The Multiband Reflectance Iteration algorithm (MBRI) is used for the retrieval of sea ice albedo under clear-sky condition, and the sea ice albedo under the cloudy condition is reconstructed by combining spatiotemporal filtering and physical model. Validation compared with the sea ice albedo measurements from two automatic weather stations of the Baseline Surface Radiation Network (BSRN) suggests that the biases at the two stations are -0.0221 and -0.0363, and root mean square error (RMSE) values are 0.0664 and 0.0754. These results indicate that this dataset exhibits superior spatiotemporal resolution and accuracy compared to existing products. This dataset is stored in GeoTIFF format, with the variable being the true albedo of sea ice, also known as blue-sky albedo. In addition, multiband reflectance data covering the shortwave range was used in the calculation process, so the dataset represents the broadband albedo of the shortwave range. The albedo is a dimensionless parameter and needs to be multiplied by a scale factor of 0.0001 when used. This dataset adopts SIN projection, with a longitude range of 180 ° W~180 ° E and a latitude range of 50 ° S~80 ° S, covering a total of 53 tiles (v14: h06~h29; v15: h09~h26; v16: h11~h17, h21~h24). The v16 tiles encompass portions of the Antarctic ice sheet and these areas need to be cropped when using the data. The ocean water area is set to a filling value of -1. This data can be used for evaluating and predicting the radiation budget and loss status of Antarctic sea ice, as well as research on climate change and other aspects.
metadata.instructions: File Naming: data is stored in GeoTIFF format, the file name is "Antarctic_Sea_Ice_Albedo_ {yyyyddd}_ {hv}_v01.tif ”, where yyyy represents year, ddd represents day of the year, hv represents the number of the tile, and v01 represents the version 01. For example, "Antarctic_Sea_Ice_Albedo_2014270_h18v15_v01. tif" represents the sea ice albedo data of the h18v15 area on the 270th day of 2014. Data reading method: It can be opened and read using software or computer languages such as ArcGIS, Envi, Python, Matlab, etc.

background: The Greenland Ice Sheet (GrIS), the second largest ice sheet on Earth (after the Antarctic Ice Sheet), is particularly sensitive to surface energy balance and sea-level changes. Surface broadband albedo, hereafter referred to as albedo, is defined as the ratio of the reflected solar radiation flux to the incident flux on the surface. In the ice- and snow-covered parts of the Arctic, albedo is a crucial indicator of the surface energy budget. A slight change in snow surface albedo can generate significant feedback on the energy budget of the surface – air system, leading to a substantial fluctuation in the energy flux on the surface of GrIS. Therefore, GrIS’s snow and ice albedo is a critical input parameter for global climate change models. With the rapid development of Earth observation (EO) and information processing technology from the 1980s until the present, the inversion of albedo by EO data has been proven to be an effective scientific method. At present, available albedo products in GrIS include the Advanced Very High Resolution Radiometer (AVHRR), the Satellite Application Facility on Climate Monitoring, the GlobAlbedo, the Multi-angle Imaging Spectroradiometer (MISR), and the Global Land Surface Satellite (GLASS) albedo products. All the aforementioned albedo products have a temporal resolution of 8 days to 1 month and a spatial resolution of 1 – 25 km. Given their coarse spatial and temporal resolutions, meeting the needs of climate change and other related studies is difficult. In recent years, albedo products with finer resolution have been widely used. They include Visible Infrared Imaging Radiometer Suite (VIIRS) and Moderate-Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) albedo products, with daily temporal resolution and spatial resolution of 500 m and 750 m. MODIS products have been shown to have the highest potential for snow and ice research because of their high spatiotemporal resolution, long time span, and free access. Numerous studies have demonstrated the excellent monitoring capability of MODIS albedo products.

To improve the spatiotemporal continuity of albedo products, considerable effort has been exerted to the tasks of cloud removal and albedo reconstruction. Studies on reconstructing albedo can be generally categorized into indirect and direct processing strategies. An indirect processing strategy aims to reconstruct albedo by improving the quality of the bidirectional reflectance distribution function (BRDF) for estimating albedo. By contrast, a direct processing strategy fills the missing pixels of existing albedo products. All the aforementioned reconstruction techniques are based on spatiotemporal information to fill albedo under clear sky condition, without considering the albedo of snow and ice in real cloudy-sky cases. In fact, clouds affect the feedback of snow and ice albedo by decreasing the short-wave radiation that reaches the surface and increasing downward long-wave radiation. Therefore, incorporating the physical role of clouds on snow and ice albedo is important, particularly in regions such as GrIS, where large amounts of snow and ice accumulate on the surface and clouds are persistent. Moreover, the high frequency of clouds in the polar regions leads to large spatial and temporal lack of remote sensing data, which is difficult to handle by most of the existing methods.

To overcome these problems, this study proposes a method for reconstructing snow and ice albedo under cloudy skies by combining spatiotemporal and physics-informed models, referred to as STPM hereafter. Among MODIS albedo products, MOD10A1 daily snow albedo developed by Klein and Stroeve on the basis of the snow bidirectional reflectance model has been validated in GrIS by Stroeve et al. and widely used. The proposed method utilizes auxiliary data, including cloud optical thickness and solar zenith angle.
The integration of spatiotemporal information and physics-informed models opens new frontiers in remote sensing data reconstruction, promising advancements in challenging environmental contexts.
research objective: On the basis of such facts, this study proposes a reconstruction method for snow and ice albedo that combines spatiotemporal information with a physics-informed model.
The objectives of the proposed method are to reconstruct albedo data continuously and to correct the effect of clouds on snow and ice albedo.
In this study, we introduce the STPM as a novel approach to reconstructing daily snow and ice albedo series in Greenland.

This paper presents a new method that couples spatiotemporal and physics-informed models to reconstruct daily snow and ice albedo series, addressing the challenge of the lack of spatiotemporal continuous albedo data for climate change studies.
challenges: However, optical satellite-derived albedo products have many voids due to the persistent cloud cover over the Greenland ice sheet. However, daily MODIS albedo products typically contain a significant number of missing data due to cloud occlusion, sensor malfunctions, and other factors. In the Arctic region, continuous cloud coverage reaches 60% – 90%, limiting the subsequent applications of MODIS albedo products.

All the aforementioned reconstruction techniques are based on spatiotemporal information to fill albedo under clear sky condition, without considering the albedo of snow and ice in real cloudy-sky cases. Moreover, the high frequency of clouds in the polar regions leads to large spatial and temporal lack of remote sensing data, which is difficult to handle by most of the existing methods.
MOD10A1 albedo data for the study area are highly incomplete in temporal and spatial terms.
Considering the effect of clouds improves the accuracy of reconstructed snow and ice albedos compared to existing methods, and the accuracy remains stable in the accumulation and ablation zones.
methods: This method uses spatio-temporal nonlocal filtering to generate the initial reference albedo for missing pixels. Then, the hypothetical clear-sky albedo is reconstructed using the Whittaker iterator. Finally, cloudy albedo is obtained on the basis of the empirical relationship between clear-sky and cloudy-sky albedos. We reconstruct albedo based on MOD10A1 for the whole Greenland region from 2001 to 2020.

First, we use a nonlocal filter model to estimate the missing albedo on the basis of spatiotemporal similar pixels. Then, we fit the variation of snow and ice albedo long time-series data by using the Whittaker iterator. Finally, cloudy pixels are estimated on the basis of the physical conversion relationship between clear-sky albedo and cloudy albedo to recover the cloudy-sky albedo of snow and ice. In practice, we set up a 100 × 100 search box within a neighborhood that is centered on the target pixel to find similar pixels. We employ a weight of each point to indicate the importance of each point in the fitting process, providing higher weights to the points with larger differences between the initial and long-term trend albedos. We randomly select 2 years of measured albedo and reconstructed clear-sky albedo for the period of 2001 – 2020 to fit the regression coefficients of the empirical relationship, which, in this study, are selected for 2010 and 2012.
The STPM method is applied to GrIS and validated using 20 years of field data from 28 widely distributed sites.
dataset: Among MODIS albedo products, MOD10A1 daily snow albedo developed by Klein and Stroeve on the basis of the snow bidirectional reflectance model has been validated in GrIS by Stroeve et al. and widely used. It's worth noting that we utilize cloud optical thickness data from the PATMOS-x/AVHRR cloud climatology, which currently offers the highest resolution data available for the GrIS region. Within the MODIS v006 ensemble, the MCD43A3 albedo with a spatial resolution of 500 m is the latest version of the albedo product. In addition, we use the GLASS02B06 albedo product, an eight-day MODIS-based dataset from the GLASS albedo series with an initial resolution of 1 km.

The in situ measurements of albedos from 12 GC-NET AWSs located in the accumulation area of GrIS from 2001 to 2020 (except 2010 and 2012) are used to validate the reconstructed snow and ice albedo. We used PROMICE albedo for 16 sites from 2001 to 2020 (except 2010 and 2012) to verify the reconstructed albedo’s accuracy.
findings: A comparison between the reconstruction results and ground measurements exhibits satisfactory accuracy with an R-value of 0.8162, a root-mean-square error of 0.0669, a mean absolute error of 0.0486, and a bias of 0.00001. Moreover, the proposed method demonstrates the advantages of being more accurate and robust than other classical methods.

Our research underscores the exceptional accuracy of the STPM method in reconstructing daily snow and ice albedo in Greenland. The reconstructed albedo outperforms existing products like MCD43A3 and GLASS in terms of accuracy and spatial coverage.

Compared to MCD43A3 and GLASS data, reconstructed data captures more accurate albedo variations. The contribution of this paper is to provide a method to seamlessly reconstruct GrIS daily snow and ice albedo data, suggesting a new solution to the albedo remote sensing data reconstruction problem.

Definition.Question: What does 'albedo reconstruction' mean in the context of polar ice studies?
Definition.Answer: Albedo reconstruction in the context of polar ice studies refers to the process of generating accurate albedo values under various conditions, such as cloudy skies, by using models and algorithms that incorporate spatiotemporal information and the physical effects of clouds. This involves strategies to fill in data gaps typically caused by cloud cover or sensor malfunctions, using methods like spatio-temporal nonlocal filtering and empirical relationships between clear-sky and cloudy-sky albedos.

Definition.Question: How is 'spatiotemporal continuity' achieved in albedo datasets?
Definition.Answer: Spatiotemporal continuity in albedo datasets is achieved by employing methods that address the gaps in data caused by factors such as cloud cover. Techniques include spatio-temporal nonlocal filtering to estimate missing data, and the use of physics-informed models that consider the impact of clouds on albedo. These methods ensure continuous and accurate albedo data over time and space, which is crucial for climate change studies.

Definition.Question: What is the role of 'cloud optical thickness' in reconstructing albedo datasets?
Definition.Answer: Cloud optical thickness plays a crucial role in reconstructing albedo datasets by providing auxiliary information that helps in estimating the albedo under cloudy conditions. It is used in models to correct the effects of clouds on the albedo data, thereby improving the accuracy of the reconstructed albedo, especially in regions with persistent cloud cover like the polar ice sheets.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for the Antarctic sea ice albedo dataset compare to those used in reconstructing albedo under cloudy skies in Greenland, particularly in terms of handling cloud cover and data gaps?
Comparison.Answer: The Antarctic sea ice albedo dataset uses a multiband reflectance iteration algorithm to reconstruct albedo under cloud cover, incorporating spatiotemporal filtering and physical models to fill gaps. In contrast, the Greenland albedo reconstruction method combines spatiotemporal information with physics-informed models, specifically addressing cloud effects by using spatio-temporal nonlocal filtering and empirical relationships to reconstruct albedo under cloudy conditions. Both methods aim to improve the spatial and temporal continuity of albedo data in the presence of cloud cover.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences between the spatial and temporal resolutions of the Antarctic sea ice albedo dataset and the MODIS-based albedo products used for Greenland, and how might these affect the application of each dataset in climate studies?
Comparison.Answer: The Antarctic sea ice albedo dataset offers a spatial resolution of 1 km and a daily temporal resolution, covering a period from 2012 to 2021. The MODIS-based products for Greenland, such as MOD10A1 and MCD43A3, provide spatial resolutions of 500 m and 750 m with daily temporal resolution. These differences in resolution may influence their application in climate studies, with the Antarctic dataset potentially offering broader spatial coverage while the MODIS products provide finer spatial details, which can be crucial for detecting local albedo variations in climate models.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of persistent cloud cover and missing data affect the reconstruction accuracy of albedo datasets in Antarctic and Greenland regions, and how do the respective methodologies address these challenges?
Comparison.Answer: Persistent cloud cover and missing data are significant challenges in both regions. The Antarctic dataset addresses these by using a combination of multiband reflectance iteration and spatiotemporal filtering to reconstruct albedo under cloudy conditions. The Greenland methodology uses spatio-temporal nonlocal filtering and empirical relationships to estimate cloudy-sky albedo, focusing on correcting cloud effects on snow and ice albedo. Both approaches aim to mitigate data voids caused by clouds, enhancing the reconstruction accuracy of albedo datasets.

Interpretation.Question: How can data collection methods be refined to better capture snow and ice albedo under persistent cloudy conditions in polar regions?
Interpretation.Answer: To address the challenges of persistent cloud cover affecting albedo data, a combination of spatiotemporal and physics-informed models can be utilized. This approach involves reconstructing albedo by integrating cloud optical thickness and solar zenith angle data, which helps in estimating clear-sky and cloudy-sky albedo more accurately.

Interpretation.Question: What are the key challenges in ensuring the accuracy and completeness of datasets used for reconstructing albedo data in polar ice regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Key challenges include dealing with the high frequency of clouds that cause significant data voids, sensor malfunctions, and the need for reconstruction techniques that can fill these gaps without compromising the accuracy of snow and ice albedo measurements. Existing methods often struggle with the spatial and temporal continuity of data due to these factors.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for cloud removal and albedo reconstruction in albedo datasets for polar regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The high frequency of clouds in polar regions leads to significant spatial and temporal gaps in remote sensing data, necessitating cloud removal and albedo reconstruction to improve the spatiotemporal continuity of albedo products.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to incorporate the physical role of clouds in the reconstruction of snow and ice albedo datasets?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Incorporating the physical role of clouds is crucial because clouds affect the feedback of snow and ice albedo by decreasing the short-wave radiation reaching the surface and increasing downward long-wave radiation, which is particularly significant in regions with persistent cloud cover.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in maintaining the accuracy and consistency of albedo data in areas like Greenland Ice Sheet?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Persistent cloud cover, sensor malfunctions, and the high frequency of clouds contribute to significant gaps and voids in optical satellite-derived albedo products, impacting the accuracy and consistency of albedo data in areas like the Greenland Ice Sheet.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a multiband reflectance iteration algorithm for reconstructing albedo under cloudy conditions in polar regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a multiband reflectance iteration algorithm can lead to improved accuracy and spatiotemporal resolution of albedo datasets by effectively reconstructing albedo under cloudy conditions. This approach enhances the dataset's ability to regulate Earth's radiation budget and control polar climate changes, which are crucial for climate change research.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended objectives of reconstructing albedo data for snow and ice under cloudy conditions using spatiotemporal and physics-informed models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objectives are to continuously reconstruct albedo data and to correct the effect of clouds on snow and ice albedo, which is essential for addressing the lack of spatiotemporal continuous albedo data needed for climate change studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is there a need to develop datasets with high spatiotemporal resolution for monitoring snow and ice albedo in polar regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: High spatiotemporal resolution is needed because existing albedo products often have large voids due to persistent cloud cover, leading to significant gaps in data that can impede the understanding and monitoring of climate change effects in these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in reconstructing snow and ice albedo data under cloudy conditions to improve spatiotemporal continuity?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The reconstruction of snow and ice albedo data under cloudy conditions involves using a spatio-temporal nonlocal filtering method to generate initial reference albedo for missing pixels, reconstructing hypothetical clear-sky albedo using the Whittaker iterator, and obtaining cloudy albedo based on the empirical relationship between clear-sky and cloudy-sky albedos. This method combines spatiotemporal information with physics-informed models to handle the lack of continuous data due to cloud cover.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approach is adopted to ensure the accuracy of reconstructed albedo data in regions with high cloud coverage?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure accuracy in regions with high cloud coverage, a methodological approach that combines spatiotemporal information and physics-informed models is adopted. This involves using a nonlocal filter to estimate missing albedo values, applying the Whittaker iterator for clear-sky albedo reconstruction, and establishing a physical conversion relationship between clear-sky and cloudy-sky albedos. Additionally, empirical relationships are fitted using measured albedo data to refine the reconstruction process.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the reconstruction of albedo data under cloudy conditions for polar regions?
Enablement.Answer: Combining spatiotemporal information with physics-informed models, such as the Multiband Reflectance Iteration Algorithm (MBRI) and spatio-temporal nonlocal filtering, enables the reconstruction of albedo data under cloudy conditions. This approach helps to integrate the physical role of clouds in the albedo feedback mechanism, particularly in regions with persistent cloud cover like the polar regions.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the generation of high-resolution albedo datasets for climate change studies?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements in Earth observation and information processing, such as the use of VIIRS 1 km surface reflectance products and MODIS albedo products, have enabled the generation of high-resolution albedo datasets. These advancements include improved spatial and temporal resolutions, allowing for more precise monitoring of snow and ice albedo, which is critical for climate change studies.

Expectation.Question: Why might albedo reconstruction methods often face challenges in handling the high frequency of clouds in polar regions?
Expectation.Answer: Albedo reconstruction methods face challenges in handling the high frequency of clouds in polar regions because continuous cloud coverage leads to large spatial and temporal gaps in remote sensing data, which are difficult to address with most existing methods. Additionally, these methods typically focus on clear sky conditions without considering the albedo of snow and ice under actual cloudy-sky cases.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected advantages of integrating spatiotemporal information with physics-informed models for albedo data reconstruction?
Expectation.Answer: Integrating spatiotemporal information with physics-informed models for albedo data reconstruction opens new frontiers in remote sensing data reconstruction. This integration promises advancements in challenging environmental contexts, such as improving the accuracy of reconstructed snow and ice albedos by considering the physical effects of clouds.

Expectation.Question: Why is the reconstruction of snow and ice albedo under cloudy skies considered important for climate change studies?
Expectation.Answer: Reconstructing snow and ice albedo under cloudy skies is considered important for climate change studies because clouds affect the feedback mechanism of snow and ice albedo by decreasing short-wave radiation reaching the surface and increasing downward long-wave radiation. Addressing these factors improves the continuity and accuracy of albedo data, which is crucial for climate models and understanding polar climate dynamics.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you find the use of the Multiband Reflectance Iteration Algorithm (MBRI) in reconstructing the albedo under cloud conditions for improving data accuracy?
Judgmental.Answer: The Multiband Reflectance Iteration Algorithm (MBRI) is effective in reconstructing albedo under cloud conditions as it allows for the derivation of cloud-free sea ice albedo, which improves the dataset's temporal and spatial continuity. The comparison with BSRN stations indicates a lower bias and RMSE, demonstrating its superior accuracy over similar international products.
